turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Marie-Joseph Chénier.
turn.1: What happened in 1792 to Marie-Joseph Chénier?
turn.2: In 1792 he produced his "Caïus Gracchus", which was even more revolutionary in tone than its predecessors.
turn.3: What was the Ca ⁇ us Gracchus?
turn.4: It was nevertheless proscribed in the next year at the instance of the Montagnard deputy Albitte, for the anti-anarchical hemistich "Des lois et non du sang" ("Laws, and not blood"); "Fénelon" (1793) was suspended after a few representations; and in 1794 "Timoléon", set to Etienne Méhul's music, was also proscribed.
turn.6: This piece was played after the Reign of Terror, but the fratricide of "Timoléon" became the text for insinuations to the effect that by his silence Joseph Chénier had connived at the judicial murder of his brother, André, whom Joseph's enemies alluded to as Abel.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: In fact, after some fruitless attempts to save his brother, variously related by his biographers, Joseph became aware that André's only chance of safety lay in being forgotten by the authorities, and that ill-advised intervention would only hasten the end.
turn.9: What did he do after that?
turn.10: Joseph Chénier had been a member of the National Convention and had voted for the death of Louis XVI; he belonged to the committees of general security, and of public safety.
turn.12: He was, nevertheless, suspected of moderate sentiments, and before the end of the Terror had become a marked man.
